text:
The M.T.A. has raised fares every two years to offset the rising costs of providing service. With growing concerns over the affordability of living in New York, mass-transit advocates have called on Mayor Bill de Blasio to budget for a program to offer reduced fares for low-income riders. 
Advertisement The subway fare increase comes at a time when there are more delays and more crowding in train cars. Since 2012, subway delays have more than doubled to about 70,000 per month. Here’s what else is happening: Weather We made it: Today is the first day of spring. We’re in for a chilly week, but a lovely one. Though it might feel as nippy as 25 degrees with the wind this morning, highs will climb to 53 later today — and the sunshine is here to stay for the foreseeable future. So “spread sunshine all over the place, just put on a happy face .” In the News • Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo plots the demise of the Bronx’s Sheridan Expressway, the highway built by Robert Moses. [ New York Times ] Photo Governor Cuomo has endorsed a $700 million plan to tear down the Sheridan Expressway. Credit Gregg Vigliotti for The New York Times 
  • There’s a push to lift graduation rates at the City University of New York, the largest urban public university system in the country. [ New York Times ] • The city is holding a contest to design the next “I Voted” sticker to be handed out during the municipal elections on Nov. 7. [ New York Times ] Photo The “I Voted” sticker became a social media star in the 2016 election, appearing in countless selfies and at the graves of several suffragists. Credit Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times 
Advertisement • A children’s theater program focusing on Muslim stories was suspended at a city public school because critics said it violated the constitutional line separating church and state. [ WNYC ] • New Jersey’s historic Woodland Cemetery, which opened in 1855, sits neglected. [ New York Times ] Photo “The cemetery has been failing our community for decades,” Karima Jackson of New Jersey said. Credit Christopher Occhicone for The New York Times 
Advertisement • A 22-year-old man died after being shot in the face at a nightclub in Bushwick, Brooklyn. [ Gothamist ]
